Body:
BC-PHOTO-FULL-UPDATE-NYT 
   ATTENTION EDITORS: The following photos are part of tonight's
New York Times Photo Package, moving 04/02/99. Photo clients will
automatically receive these photos via AP's PhotoExpress or may
download them from either the Wieck Photo Database in Dallas at
972-392-0888 or from NYTPhotos on Newscom at 305-448-8411.
Non-clients can make individual purchases by calling (888) 603-1036
or 212-556-4204.

   (NYT35) PHOENIX -- April 2, 1999 -- BRUNCH-FOOD-AZR, 4-01 --
Brunch is the ultimate breakfast. Guests at this table can choose
from cheese blintzes, croissants, ham glazed with pepper jelly,
fruit compote, raspberry cream cheese coffeecake and lemon-glazed
asparagus. (Paul Gero/Arizona Republic Times Photo)

   (NYT34) VATICAN CITY -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4
-- MILLENIUM-VATICAN-COX-4, 4-02 -- A woman kisses the foot of the
statue of St. Peter in St. Peter's Basilica. So many pilgrims and
tourists from around the world come to the Basilica in Vatican City
to caress the foot of the statue that it has born worn down over
the years. (Jean Shifrin/Atlanta Journal Constitution Photo)

   (NYT33) VATICAN CITY -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4
-- MILLENIUM-VATICAN-COX-3, 4-02 -- Even though he appears not much
bigger than a speck, Pope John Paul II's Sunday blessing from the
window of his study draws visitors and pilgrims from around the
world. Vatican City is ground zero for the largest Christian
denomination in the world, the center of a separate ``country''
with its own government, newspaper, radio station and publishing
house. (Jean Shifrin/Atlanta Journal Constitution Photo)

   (NYT32) ROME -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4 --
MILLENIUM-CHRISTIANITY-COX-3, 4-02 -- It's not uncommon to see the
clash of old and new on the streets of Rome, as destrated by these
motor scooters parked beneath a wooden cross. The combination of
modern technology and old world religion abounds in this ancient
city. (Jean Shifrin/Atlanta Journal Constitution Photo)

   (NYT31) ORVIETO, Italy -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL
4 -- MILLENIUM-ORVIETO-COX-2, 4-02 -- An altar showcases the Virgin
Mary at St. Andrew and St. Bartholomew Church in Orvieto. The
church is a combined parish of about 400 families in the medieval
part of this hill town of 21,000 people in the region of Umbria
about 90 minutes from Rome. (Jean Shifrin/Atlanta Journal
Constitution Photo)

   (NYT30) VATICAN CITY -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4
-- MILLENIUM-VATICAN-COX-2, 4-02 -- Three nuns walk across St.
Peter's Square on their way to early morning Mass at St. Peter's
Basilica. Pilgrims and tourists from around the globe come to see
the largest basilica in the world, home to some of the most
important and impressive religious art anywhere. (Jean
Shifrin/Atlanta Journal Constitution Photo)

   (NYT29) ROME -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4 --
MILLENIUM-CHRISTIANITY-COX-2, 4-02 -- The faithful climb Scala
Santa in Rome, aka the Holy Stairs, on their knees. No feet are
allowed to touch the steps. This staircase is believed to be from
the palace of Pilate in Jerusalem, and were supposedly scaled by
Jesus on the day of his condemnation. The 28 marble steps have been
covered with walnut for protection. (Jean Shifrin/Atlanta Journal
Constitution Photo)

   (NYT28) CONCORD, N.H. -- April 2, 1999 -- NH-SCHOOL-TAX, 4-02 --
The New Hampshire House passed a bill late last month establishing
a state income tax, which is gaining support in polls, but then
reversed itself. New Hampshire is one of only two states without an
income or sales tax. (Evan Richman/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT27) GREAT BEND, Kan. -- April 2, 1999 -- OIL-INDEPENDENTS,
4-02 -- After 32 years in the oil industry, Dan Murta, who lives in
Great Bend, lost his job as vice president with Tomkat Ltd., a
small independent oil company based in Wichita. From a salary of
$45,000 a year, he has been reduced to earning little more than
minimum wage as a telemarketer. ``There's no opportunity out
here,'' says Murta, 56. ``I just couldn't find anything.'' (Steve
Rasmussen/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT26) HUNTSVILLE, Texas -- April 2, 1999 -- KOSOVO-U.S., 4-02
-- In Huntsville on Friday, Melissa Roose of Waco ties yellow
ribbons to the fence outside the Texas Department of Criminal
Justice headquarters in honor of Spc. Steven Gonzales - one of
three U.S. soldiers being held captive by Serb forces. Gonzales'
mother, Rosie, works in the building. (Steve Campbell/Houston
Chronicle)

   (NYT25) CHICAGO -- April 2, 1999 -- BUSINESS-TRAVEL, 4-02 -- In
February, Laura Hiller was one of many passengers put out by the
American Airlines sickout. Poor service, scant leg room, lost or
mishandled baggage, incomplete or misleading information about
delayed flights, overbooking and frustration with frequent-flier
miles that are easy to accumulate but next to impossible to use -
all are laments still heard involving air travel. (Todd
Buchanan/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT24) SHANGHAI, CHINA -- April 2, 1999 -- BIZ-CHINA-SPEND,
4-02 -- Shanghai workers push ahead with the Yanan Road Elevated
Expressway, which will link the city center to the airport. Fewer
office buildings are going up, but China is pouring money into
public works. (Fritz Hoffmann/New York Times Photo) *LITE

   (NYT23) MORINI BORDER CROSSING, Albania -- April 2, 1999 --
KOSOVO-REFUGEES-2, 4-02 -- Albanian border police officers
registering ethnic Albanian refugees from Kosovo as they travel
through the Marini Border Crossing into Albania on Friday. More
than 360,000 ethnic Albanians have now made the journey, and NATO
says another 600,000 are still massed across the rugged terrain
waiting to get here. (Edward Keating/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT22) MORINI BORDER CROSSING, Albania -- April 2, 1999 --
KOSOVO-REFUGEES-1, 4-02 -- At the Morini Border Crossing on Friday,
Behije Xhana, left, working at a Kukes bakery, tells Nusret
Berisha, far right, that, due to the high demand, the wait for
bread will be three hours; bread makes up over half the diet of
Albanians. More than 360,000 ethnic Albanians have now made the
journey out of Kosovo. (Edward Keating/New York Times Photo) *LITE

   (NYT21) BLACE, Macedonia -- April 2, 1999 -- KOSOVO-MACEDONIA,
4-02 -- Ethnic Albanian refugees from Kosovo getting off a train
from Pristina, just inside the Macedonian border. Reports from the
refugees indicate that Serb forces are emptying neighborhoods and
towns in a campaign of ethnic cleansing. (Alan Chin/New York Times
Photo)

   (NYT20) ALGIERS, Algeria -- April 2, 1999 --
ALGERIA-JOURNALISTS, 4-02 -- Omar Bellouchet, editor in chief of El
Watan, in his Algiers office with a photo of Said Makbel, editor of
Le Matin, who was assassinated in 1995. ``Entrenching press freedom
in a country like this is a difficult business,'' Bellouchet says.
``You move forward, you get hit, you fall down; you get up, move
forward, get hit again.'' (John Giannini/New York Times Photo)
*LITE

   (NYT19) BOSTON -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4 --
BIZ-DOW-REACT, 4-02 -- George Herrmann thinks the Dow is just
experiencing ``a surge,'' but he has faith in technology stocks.
``If a company still has fresh ideas, it's a sound investment.''
(Jim Bourg/Wieck Photo)

   (NYT18) NEW YORK -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4 --
ABOUT-CARS-AUTOSHOW, 4-02 -- In a performance at the New York auto
show marking the 75th anniversary of the first Chrysler car, an
actor portraying Walter P. Chrysler greets Thomas T. Stallkamp,
president of DaimlerChrysler's North American operations. The new
PT Cruiser is at right. (Joe Wilssens/Wieck Photo) *LITE

   (NYT17) FISHER ISLAND, Fla. -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN.,
APRIL 4 -- FLA-FISHER-ISLAND-3, 4-02 -- Residents of Fisher Island,
an exclusive enclave in Biscayne Bay, are divided over plans for
development of hundreds of homes. ``I thought I'd be the white
knight,'' says John J. Melk, one of the developers. ``We're
downsizing, so there should be cheers and respect.'' (Susan
Greenwood/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT16) FISHER ISLAND, Fla. -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN.,
APRIL 4 -- FLA-FISHER-ISLAND-2, 4-02 -- Isadore Pines, who owns a
$4.5 million apartment that overlooks the ocean, believes that
plans by the developers who recently bought much of Fisher Island
to build 315 lavish condominiums can only diminish the current
residents' quality of life. ``This is so not my life style,'' Pines
says of his unaccustomed activism. (Susan Greenwood/New York Times
Photo)

   (NYT15) FISHER ISLAND, Fla. -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN.,
APRIL 4 -- FLA-FISHER-ISLAND-1, 4-02 -- Residents of Fisher Island,
an exclusive enclave in Biscayne Bay, are divided over plans for
development of hundreds of homes. A war between the haves and the
haves has raged for two years across this 216-acre island, which
Oprah Winfrey, Mel Brooks, retired corporate moguls and various
South American jet-setters call home - at least during the high
season. (Susan Greenwood/New York Times Photo) *LITE

   (NYT14) NEW YORK -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4 --
MUTUND-VALUE-3, 4-02 -- Larry Sondike of Franklin Mutual Advisers
still favors overlooked stocks. ``As surely as growth in certain
periods will be the rage and will attract the money and investment
for that period, it will ultimately end,'' he says. (Joyce
Dopkeen/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT13) NEW YORK -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4 --
MUTUND-VALUE-2, 4-02 -- Martin J. Whitman of Third Avenue Value is
worried about current trends. The recent market run-up is
``dangerous'' and ``scary,'' he says, reminiscent of the narrow
market dominated by the Nifty 50 in the days before the 1973-74
selloff. (Susan Farley/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT12) SUMMERLAND, Calif. -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN.,
APRIL 4 -- MUTUND-VALUE-1, 4-02 -- William J. Nasgovitz of
Heartland Value reports that client pressure is intense. ``People
are caving in,'' he says. (Edward Carreon/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT11) MADISON, Wis. -- April 2, 1999 -- CRONON-ENVIRON, 4-02
-- William Cronon, a professor in environmental history, in a
prairie at the University of Wisconsin's arboretum. He calls the
ideal of wilderness a fantasy and a threat. (Andy Manis/New York
Times Photo)

   (NYT10) NEW YORK -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4 --
MAGICIAN-BURIAL, 4-02 -- David Blaine with Kylie Bax at Joe's Pub
recently. Monday at 10 a.m., Blaine, a fin de siecle version of
Harry Houdini best known for his friendships with the Hollywood
fast crowd, will be buried, for a week, on the banks of the Hudson
River. (Miles Ladin/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT9) UNDATED -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4 --
COMMISH-SOCIAL-WHIRL, 4-02 -- New York City Police Commissioner
Howard Safir shakes hands before the Oscar ceremony. He was,
predictably, lambasted for flying to Hollywood on the heels of the
Amadou Diallo shooting. But Safir was upholding a longstanding
tradition: Upon becoming commissioner, he had automatically joined
the social A list, with all its blandishments and
career-threatening temptations. (Philip Greenberg/New York Times
Photo)

   (NYT8) BIRMINGHAM, Mich. -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN.,
APRIL 4 -- MUTFUND-4MANAGERS-4, 4-02 -- Paul T. Cook, manager of
the Munder Net Net fund, found some hefty profits in electronic
commerce and on-line brokerage businesses. ``We buy companies that
derive revenue or strategic significance from the Internet,'' he
says. (Peter Yates/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT7) DENVER -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4 --
MUTFUND-4MANAGERS-3, 4-02 -- Warren B. Lammert, who likes cable TV
stocks for his Washington Mutual Trust II Growth fund, with his
family and the morning papers. ``Cable companies will be able to
dramatically improve their basic cable, video and TV offerings as
they move from analog to digital networks,'' he says. (Kevin
Moloney/New York Times Photo) *LITE

   (NYT6) SAN FRANCISCO -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4
-- MUTFUND-4MANAGERS-2, 4-02 -- Garrett R. Van Wagoner picked up
some bargains in the quarter for Van Wagoner Emerging Growth.
``People are hooking up online, causing a tremendous amount of data
traffic growth across the country, and many different technology
sectors are benefiting from the explosion,'' he says. (Peter
DaSilva/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT5) BOSTON -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4 --
SUB-MUTFUND-4MANAGERS-1, 4-02 -- Stocks of biotechnology and
semiconductor capital equipment companies propelled Fidelity New
Millennium, managed by Neal P. Miller. ``Now, people need more
storage and faster products at the same time that fewer people are
producing them,'' he says. (Jim Bourg/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT4) NEW YORK -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4 --
SUB-MUTUND-PICKS, 4-02 -- When Mark Carhart studied fund rankings,
he found some nasty surprises. Carhart, who is co-head of
quantitative research at Goldman Sachs Asset Management, has found
that the top decile performers in any one year are more likely to
end up the next year in the bottom 10 percent. (Jack Manning/New
York Times Photo)

   (NYT3) CHICAGO -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4 --
MUTFUND-INTERNATIONAL, 4-02 -- David Herro of Oakmark International
Small Cap braved Asia and found some good deals. ``We use a style
that tries to buy good-quality businesses with good-quality
management at burnt-out prices,'' he says. (Steve Kagan/New York
Times Photo)

   (NYT2) SAN FRANCISCO -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4
-- INVEST-PHILANTHROPY, 4-02 -- Claude Rosenberg, a retired San
Francisco investment manager who is now a philanthropist, believes
that wealthy Americans get bad financial advice that leads them to
hold down their charitable giving. ``Generosity has been based too
much on income,'' he says With capital for many people being so
much larger than income there is enormous untapped capacity to
give. (Peter DaSilva/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT1) LONDON -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4 --
BIZ-PROFILE-SUNDERLAND, 4-02 -- John M. Sunderland outside Cadbury
Schweppes' London headquarters. Schweppes' elfin-faced chief
executive says he wants to bring the principles of Margaret
Thatcher to a company Wall Street has often viewed as sleepy. ``I
wanted to prove that you can do anything if you set your mind to
it,'' says Sunderland, 54. (Jonathan Player/New York Times Photo)

   The New York Times News Service
Text:
ATTENTION EDITORS: The following photos are part of tonight's
New York Times Photo Package, moving 04/02/99. Photo clients will
automatically receive these photos via AP's PhotoExpress or may
download them from either the Wieck Photo Database in Dallas at
972-392-0888 or from NYTPhotos on Newscom at 305-448-8411.
Non-clients can make individual purchases by calling (888) 603-1036
or 212-556-4204.

family and the morning papers. ``Cable companies will be able to
dramatically improve their basic cable, video and TV offerings as
they move from analog to digital networks,'' he says. (Kevin
Moloney/New York Times Photo) *LITE

   (NYT6) SAN FRANCISCO -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4
-- MUTFUND-4MANAGERS-2, 4-02 -- Garrett R. Van Wagoner picked up
some bargains in the quarter for Van Wagoner Emerging Growth.
``People are hooking up online, causing a tremendous amount of data
traffic growth across the country, and many different technology
sectors are benefiting from the explosion,'' he says. (Peter
DaSilva/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT5) BOSTON -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4 --
SUB-MUTFUND-4MANAGERS-1, 4-02 -- Stocks of biotechnology and
semiconductor capital equipment companies propelled Fidelity New
Millennium, managed by Neal P. Miller. ``Now, people need more
storage and faster products at the same time that fewer people are
producing them,'' he says. (Jim Bourg/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT4) NEW YORK -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4 --
SUB-MUTUND-PICKS, 4-02 -- When Mark Carhart studied fund rankings,
he found some nasty surprises. Carhart, who is co-head of
quantitative research at Goldman Sachs Asset Management, has found
that the top decile performers in any one year are more likely to
end up the next year in the bottom 10 percent. (Jack Manning/New
York Times Photo)

   (NYT3) CHICAGO -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4 --
MUTFUND-INTERNATIONAL, 4-02 -- David Herro of Oakmark International
Small Cap braved Asia and found some good deals. ``We use a style
that tries to buy good-quality businesses with good-quality
management at burnt-out prices,'' he says. (Steve Kagan/New York
Times Photo)

   (NYT2) SAN FRANCISCO -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4
-- INVEST-PHILANTHROPY, 4-02 -- Claude Rosenberg, a retired San
Francisco investment manager who is now a philanthropist, believes
that wealthy Americans get bad financial advice that leads them to
hold down their charitable giving. ``Generosity has been based too
much on income,'' he says With capital for many people being so
much larger than income there is enormous untapped capacity to
give. (Peter DaSilva/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT1) LONDON -- April 2, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., APRIL 4 --
BIZ-PROFILE-SUNDERLAND, 4-02 -- John M. Sunderland outside Cadbury
Schweppes' London headquarters. Schweppes' elfin-faced chief
executive says he wants to bring the principles of Margaret
Thatcher to a company Wall Street has often viewed as sleepy. ``I
wanted to prove that you can do anything if you set your mind to
it,'' says Sunderland, 54. (Jonathan Player/New York Times Photo)
